Sequence Information.Peptide Name: Circulin B (CirB, natural AMPs; XXC; cyclotides; UCBB1aB; flowering seed plants; ZZHp; 3S=S)

Literature Information.Literature: Activity: Active against Gram- E. coli (MIC 0.41 uM), P. aeruginosa (MIC 25.5 uM), P. vulgaris (MIC 6.8 uM), K. oxytoca (MIC 8.2 uM), Gram+ S. aureus (MIC 13.5 uM), M.luteus (MIC >500 uM), fungi C.albicans (MIC > 500 uM), C. kefyr (MIC 29 uM), and C.tropicalis (MIC >500 uM) (See ref AP00729, Tam JP et al. PNAS 96:8913-8). It also inhibited HIV-1 infection in cultured human T-lymphoblast (CEM-SS) cells (EC50 40-260 nM) and cytotoxicity (TC50 500 nM), therapeutic index (2-12)(Ireland et al., 2008).Antimicrobial robustness: NaCl-sensitive:E. coli (100 mM); NaCl-sensitive:P. vulgaris (100 mM); NaCl-sensitive:K. oxytoca (100 mM); NaCl-sensitive:C. kefyr (100 mM).Structure:  It is cyclic and contains three disulfide bonds (Tam JP et al. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 1999; 96: 8913-8918).You can rotate, zoom, and view the 3D structureherein the PDB.Updated 8/10/2015; 7/2021; 11/2023.
Literature Information.Author: Hayashi K, Suketa Y, Suzuki T.1968
Literature Information.Title: Chemical structure of circulin B.
